div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.
Commencing from October 1st the through Scosmers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said every Monday at 5 p.m.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de oxe via Brindigi or via Marseilles £ 19.4.11.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suskin direct returning from Suskin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suskin, Masowsh, Hedeidsh, Adan. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyon Jeddah bat call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Tambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 11, 1906.

div.head: THE SITUATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: We do not sahre the opinions of the "Daily Express" and the "Evening Standard and St. James' Gazette," which have given us a very pretty and inspirting picture of picked companies of the Army of Occupation sleeping in their boots, clasping their rifles to their bosoms, and enduring the weight of 250 rounds og ballcartridege. As the pouches now worn by the British soldier do not carry more than 100 rounds, we may be excused for displaying a certain scepticism as to the military knowledge of our contemporary's informant. As for his statement that seditious lanauge and anti British harangues can be heard at a certain night-school we imagine that they can be heard at most of the higehr students' debating clubs and in numerous bars where a certain type of "Europeanised" Moslem congregates.

One may also study the workings of the "Nationalist" mind by studying the outpourings of Mustapha Psha Kamel and many others, and the conclusion that there is considerable unrest among the talkative classes isalmost capavle of mathematical demonstration. Further, we believe that a certain number of ulema have harangued the faithfyl in a style more suited to field preachers than 60 religious dinitaries, and its is quite possible to work up a very pretty theory of a vast conspiracy to undo the work that Great Britain has accomplished since 1882. Fortunately there is alarge element - less articulate perhaps than the loquacious gentlemen with pointed boots and the latest thing in ties who pass such vigorous resolution and talk so gaily of regenerating Egypt by themselves, and less in touch with the externals of European civilisation - which has a very shrewd notion of its intersts, and appreciates the ideas of tolerance and justic far more thoroughly than some of the products of our secondary schools. Among this class may be reckoned the great majority of the fellaheen, the mercantile class, and most of the large propvincial land owners. We quite grant that some of the latter, perhaps some of the merchants, would prefer, in theory, to see the Egyptian governing themselves. We do not blame them for their feelings. We realise that in practice they prefer to leave well aone and trust to the increase of education and the growth of the civic virtues among Egyptian to bring about that consummation at long last. As for the fellaheen - with the exception perhaps of some of the Menoufieh people - they want water and justice - voila tout. In time their wants may be extended to platforms and ballot boxes, but that time has not yet come, and for the present these fellaheen - five-sixths of the population of Egypt - desire to be allowed to ass piastre to piastre, die, and pray in their own fashion.

As for our agitators - apostles in the open or in secret of the gospel of Yildiz - they have a certain following of whom exist in Egypt as in most Moslem and christian countries, imposters, partisans of reaction, and idealists who image that the millenium will come if every Effendi has a votes, hangers on of the court and men "on the make" who - realising that "Nationalism" and anglophobia are in great demand just now hasten to supply the consumer with great pleasure and profit to themselves. There are also some real patriots who idealism has obscured their common sense, who follow the "Lewa" and till lately helped to give Mustapha Psha Kamel an excellent reclame that their guide is so fond of heading the procession that he has led them many weary miles rfom their goal: but that is their affair. We can only condole and wish them a better choice.

With such materials at the disposal of the Nationalist party we need not be afraid of any really serious trouble. A few of our cafe haunting Beys may be rudes than usual to unprotected European ladies - a subject to which we will revert later. A few students may incite their friends to go on strike, to the great detriment of their careers, and there will be quantities of what Sir Syed Ahmed Khan described as buk-buk0buk and giz-giz-giz (scratching of a reed pen) but that will be all, in our opinion. We admit we are no more infallible than Old Moore or the illustrious Zadkiel, and that the proverb ex Africa semper aliquic nour may be proved true in our case. Still we hold by our opinion, fortified by the certainity that it represents the view of many of our readers and recommend the doubters to find a mental station half way between the pesimism of a Cassandra and the optimism of the ill starred Pangloss.

div.head: The Grand Mufti.
div.p: The "Lews" denies the report of the GRand Mufti of Egypt having been recalled.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: On the 9th inst., an aged native was found dead from plague at Haret el TArandi, Kiem Goomrock, Alexandria. A further case has been admitted to , and a death taken places in hopsital, at Suez.
Alexandria Carrison.

Of the details of the King's Royal Rifles who disembarked from the Sicilia this morning 160 will be stationed at Mustapha and 100 at Ras-el-Tin Barracks. They marched through the town on their way to the barracks.
Esbekieh Gardens.

Tomorrow eveing will be the last ocassion this year on which the military bands will play in the Esbekieh Gardens. Lack of space necesitates the postponement of the publication of the programme until tomorrow.
Fire at Port Said.

A serious fire was threatened at Port Said on Tuesday evening on the Quai Francois, facing the ahrbour, but was averted by the promptness with which the local fire brigade arrived on the scene and the effectiveness with which they worked. The fire was caused by the sparks from a chimney.
Suez Canal.

On October 9, 13 vessels, of which 4 were nothward and 9 southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 314,655.53. Of these 7 were British, 2 Dutch, 1 German, 2 American, and 1 Danish. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 2,381,752.14, and during that time 92 vessels transited the Canal, 41 being northward, and 51 southward bound.
Record Passenger Lists.

In reference to the report supplied to us by the Cairo agency of the Nordetucher Lloyd, which stated the arrival of 350 passengers by the Hohenzollern constitued a record, we are aked to point out that 720 passengers arrived by the Khedivial mail steamer Osmanieh on the 23rd September, 800 by the Ismailia on the 1st inst., and 587 by the Osmanieh last Sunday.
White Slave Traffic.

Baraon Feliz de Menasce, who has greatly interested himself in the efforts that are being made at Alexandria to suppress the white slave traffic, has gone to Paris in order to attend the third congress fo rthe suppression the 22nd inst. The President of the French Republic, M. Fallieres, will preside. M. Mauriee Herzenstein, the Secretary of the Alexandria Burean of the White Slave Trade Repression, has left Egypt in order to atten the congress.
Bandmann Company at Caire.

On the 23rd inst. the Bandmann Light Opera Company will begin a series of performances at the Khedivial Opera House at Cairo. The repertoire will include: Lasdy Madcap, The Runaway Girl, The Catch of the Season, Aladdin, Sergent Brue, The Spring Chicken, The Little Michus, The Geisha, The Ears and the Girl, The Belle of New York, A Chinese Honeymoon, the final piece being given on Monday, the 5th Novemeber, when Florodora will be given.
Practical Arabic Lessons.

The which foreginers - tourists or resident - have need of in this country in certainly not literary Arabic; but to konw well current Arabic. The Berlitz Schools of Alexandria 12 rue Rosette, and of Cairo 1 Sharia Kamel have established a special course of Arabic lessons, which enables the pupils to learn in a short time the strict necessaries for understanding, and for making themselves understood easily. The first Berlitz principle is observed in this, as in the teaching of all other foreign lanagues. Free trail lessons given.

div.head:
THE FISHERIES AGITATION.
CLERGY URGE VIGOROUS ACTION.

div.p: The agitation regardi ng th eFisheries question is growing. The clergy of all creeds are urging the Government to take vigorous action with the object of nullifying the modus vivendi with America. Two Colonial cruisers have been ordere to the Bay Islands to begin patrolling. (Reuter)

The Foreign Office has published the full summary of the modus vivendi with American concerning the Newfoundland Herring Fisheries. Great Britain undertakes not to enfore the law recently passed by the Newfoundland Legislature, aimed expressly at preventing American fishermen from profiting by local advantages. She also counsents to the Americans using purse and seins, to which the Newfoundlanders particularly object. America agrees that no fishing will take place on Sundaus in order to confrom with certain colonial regulations.She also understakes to ship no Newfoundlanders for work on American vessels except outside territorial limits. The indignation in Newfoundlanders is wholly unassuaged by the publication of the modusvivendi. The Imperial Government is accused of trampling on colonial rights. The colony has resolved to make use of every means to impede American fisherman. (Reuter)

div.head: TANTAH AGRICULTURAL SHOW.
EXCITEMENT OF THE POPULACE.
div.p: THE KHEDIVE'S VISIT.
(FROM THE OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT).

Tantah is agog with excitement. For the first time in the history of the Khedivial Agricultral Society tht annual Show is bein gheld at Tantah, though I am told that some forty-five years ago a similar exhibition, on a smaller scle, was held here under other suspices. The civil world in engala, and has foresaken work to participate in the town's rejoincing; offical-dom , overwhelmed with the resonsibility, is fused end worried lest any hitch should occur. The organisation, however, of the day's proceedings appears to guarantee that everything will go well, for, as far as the layman can judge, no detail had been imperfectly arranged.

The decoations exlipse all previous efforts for the many mouleds that this town has seen, and everything is ready to give a fitting welcome to his Highness the Khedive. The tow main platforms of the station are a blaze of red with the numberless O: to man banners, which surround shields on which are inscribed in golden letters the Khedivial monogram, topped by a crown. Opposite the exit the pillars are draped with the heavy satyer curtains and at the approach to the station triumphal arches decked in red, green, and white have been erected. The streets are lined on either sie with lofty poles bound in red and white cloth and surmounted by the star and crescent and at the corner of the road leading to the show ground there is another triumphal arch.

A large area, formerly given over the refuse, to the noth east of the station and in front of the Government schools has been converted into an excellent and well arranged show ground. Close to the entrance are the marwuees for the Khedive, the committee, and the Khedivial luncheon. Long tents have been pitched for the cotton and grain exhibits, the native industries are to be seen in temporary wooden shops, and the animals ranging from camels to guinea-pigs are well arranged according to class. The committee in composed of six members: Mohamed Bey Abou el Izz. Ibrahim Bey Bahgat, Hamid Effendi Ismail Aamir, Mohamed Bey el Sherif, Ahmed Bey el Sheikh, and Hafiz Bey el Menshawi, with Mohamed Effendi Huussein as secretary, under the presidency of Hassan Pasha Radwan, Moudir of Gharbieh. Great credit is due to this committee and to Mr.G Foaden and the staff of the Khedivial Agricultural Society for the excellent manner in which all the details have been arranged.

First among the exhibits comes the cotton which is arranged in two tents one of which is devoted to Mit Afifi and the second to Abbassi and Yanovitch. The cotton is exhibited both as it comes from the bolls and ginned and the seeds are also on show and we are glad to note that it is distincly superior in quality to that of last year. The grains, too, are well represented and fully up to standard.

Great interest is attached to the exhibitation of the Prison Department, which shows many examples of the various articles produced by the industrial section. Carriage harness was exceptionally fine work and quite equal to European products. Dogcart harness was shown of that class most in demand in Egypt. The cart harness also appeared to us of a durable manufacture; the sample shown was in brown leather, very strongly made for town and municipal work. Doormats, cocoa nut matting, carpets, and various examples of weaving, together with good workmanship in carpenters, crafts, were features of the exhibition. A very wide selection of brushes was on view from bott brushes to sweet sweepers; these all show a perfection in the insutrial department we had not anticipated. Wood turning in the way of walking sticks, fly whisks, and sundry articles of the same material were in evidence. These include ivory, hippo-horn, and bone. I can readily congratulate and workmanship of the articles manufactured.

Large crowds lined the streets at the hour for the arrival of the Khedivial train approached and every point of vantage was seized upon. The troops which arrived early this morning by special train and which number 50 cavalry and 150 infantry are lining the Sikka el Ghedidah and everybody was on the tip-toe of expectation. The telegraph staff is kept busy by a crowd of journalists.

The Khedivial train drw up at the main platform punctually at a quarter to eleve, and his Highness, who was accompanied by the ministers, Ahmed Ghali Pasha, Yusef Ria Pasha Mustapha Ibadi Pasha, Mohamed Izzat Bey, and Ahmed Shefik Bey, was greeted by Princes Hassein Pasha Kamel, Omar Pasha Toussoum, Said Pasha Hadid, the President of the Native Tribunal, the Coptic, Greek, and Maronite priests of Tantah, and the chiefs of the various administrations. As the train drew up a salute of 21 guns was fired and the band played the Khedivial Anthem.

The Khedive first drove along the Sikka el Ghedida, preceded to the Show ground, where he held a reception, which was attended by the ulma officals of the grade of mirmivan, and the vice consuls of the town. After this reception his Highness inspected with interest the many and varied exhibits and at the time of wiring, the luncheon, to which 114 guests have been invited, is being held. After lunch the Khedive will hold another reception for officals of the rank of moutesiz and sanieh, and officers of the rank of bimbashi and up wards, ahe will leave for Cairo at 3.5 p.m.
The streets are almost impassible and the excitement of the natives is intense.

div.head: NATIONAL UNIVERSITY.
PRACTICAL JOKING.
div.p: SUPPORT OF CHRISTIANS.

It is unfortunate that at the very beginings of the scheme of the new national univesity the lists of subscriptions, as announced in the vernacular Press, should have been found to be in great measure fictitions and the vast donations that have been ascribed to many native notables are being repudiated. It appears that the native journalist's idea of an excellent practical joke is to publish announcements that such and such Moslem grandee has promised an enormous sum of money for the univeristy, although no such undertaking had ever given many of the victims will not have the moral courage to repudiate these fictitous tributes to their generous enthusiasm for the scheme. This method of swelling the subscription list has no doubt some efficacy, but many of the victims are protesting. For instance "Al Minbar" published a special edition a few days ago in order to tell the world that Aly Pasha Fehmy, a former engineer in the Irrgiation Department, whose only child, a daughter, is married to Prince Fadel, had understaken to subscribe £100,000 to the Unveristy. Enormous publicity was given to this alleged generosity of the Pasha, but his Excellency contradicted the announcement of "Al Minbar" in the columns of "Al Lews."

There are many other instances, Mohamed Effendi Bazera, whose name appears on the list of the subscribers to the University, writes to inform "Al Lews" that he has been the victim of a practical joke and has not subscribed a pistre. "Al Mokattam" states that it has received a letter bearing the signature of the wakil of Ahmed Bey Cherif stating that the report that his employer had presented L.E. 10,000 and 100 feddans is absolutely unfourned. Nobody knows who has actually subscribed.

"Al Watan" remarls: - Questions have been asked as to the reason of the abstention of the Copts from subscribing to the proposed University. We believe that as a mater of fact, they are merly waiting for the formation of the Committee and the elaboration of a programme. We have no doubts as to their generosity.
"Al Abram" also states that a number of Syrian notables have met and decided to combine to forward the total of their subscriptions to the University Committee, when formed.
Our contemporary adds: "We learn that many Europeans habe also decided to open their purses in aid of the subscription."

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY IN SUDAN.
div.p: REDUCTION OF CAVALRY.

It has been decided to decrease the Cabalry of the Egyptian Army stationed in the Sudan to one squadron, while the Camel Corps will be increaed by the addition of another Arab company recruited in Kordofan. The Arab battalion at Kassals, which was reduced to a strength of 300 men after the Sudan War, will be brought up to a strength of four or five hundred. We understand that the new battalion of Sudanese will be raised if possible during the next financial year.

div.head: SUDAN EDUCATION DEPARTMENT.
div.p: The following return of the schools with the number of pupils inspected or controlled by the Sudan Education Department in 1905-06 should be interest: -
3 Training Colleges: Gordon college, Khartoum, 903, Suskin, 2, Omndurman, 27;
One Higher School: Gordon College, 15.
3 Higher Elementary Schools: Gordon College, 182, Omdurman, 166;
Instructional Worshops; Suskin, 100, Gordon College, 92;

14 Elementary Vernascular Schools; Khartoum, 93, Omdurman, 130, Halfa, 63, Suskin, 46, Berber, 84, El Damer, 34, Shendy, 26, Matemmah, 21, Rutaa, 109, W. Medani, 62, Kassals, 40, Gedarif, 70, Dongols, 35, Getanina, 30.
The total number of pupils is 1,533. Of the pupils reconed by nationality 1,227 are natives of the Sudan, 220 are Egyptians, 86 are Jews, Greeks, Syrians, etc.
The religions census of the schools shows a total of 1,419 Moslems, 107 Christians, 7 Jews and miscellaneous.
The racial statistics of the Sudan antives are also of interset: 614 pupils are ARabs, 134 belong to various Black tribes, 133 are Berberines, 345 are of mixed origin.
The Berberines preponderate at Halfa and Kassals form the whole school population of Dongola and Gateina and are well represented at Omdurman.
Pupils of mized race are proptionately most numerous at the large centres, Khartoum, Omdurman, Berber, El Damir, and Kassala.
The Blacks are mainly to be found at Khartoum and Oxdurman, Arabas at these towns, Berber (40 out of 84) Rufaa (107 out of 109) Wad Medani (58 out of 62) Gadarif (70 out of 70) and Shendi 6 Metamma.

div.head: THE COLDSTREAM GUARDS.
ARRIVAL AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: HISTORY OF THE REGIMENT.

Early this morning the 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards, numbering 29 officers and 730 of other ranks under the command of Colonel Granville Smith, who left Aldershot for Southampton on the 29th ult., where it embarked arrived at Alexandria on the S.S. Sicillia. On obard were also detail fo the Kings Royal Rifles, Sixth Dargoon Guards, Royal Garrison Artillery, Royla Horse Artillery, Army Service Corps, Royal Engineers, etc. Two special trains were departed to Cairo this morning at 11.30 a.m. and 1.30 p.m. and the Guards are due at Abbasshieh this afternoon. as already announced by us the gallant cold streamers got a royal send off at Aldershot, and at Southamption, the mangnificient weather bring out many spectators in addtion to the many friends of the battalion, military and civilian.

The 3rd Battalion is the junior one of that destinguished regiment. It was added to tit less than a decade ago, when a Government was in power which had some respect for Imperial intersts, and preferred to sacrific power rather than uield to popular clap-trap. We need hardly say that the Coldstream Guards have a reputation second to none in the British Army both in peace and war, and their prowess on the field is amply attested to by the long roll of honours which adorns the folds of the regimental colours - Oudenarde, Malplaquet, Dettingen, Lincelles, Talavera, Barroa, Penisula, Waterloo, alma, Inkerman, Sebastopol, Egypt three times already in their history.

The regiment came in to existence at the Restoration of 1660. It is a matter of history how General Monk marched from the border village of Coldstream to put Charles II. on the throne of Grea Britian, an din commemoration of that circumstance the regiment which partly formed his force was subsequently styled the Coldstream Guards. As a matter of fact the regiment had been in existence from 1650 as part of the Comwellian army. The regiment, and the Royal Horse Guards (Blues) are the only regiments now in existence that were in Cromwell's army. The Coldstreamers saw a good deal of service in the reign of Charles II and his unfortune brother James II. At the Revolution the regiment went over the popular side, disgusted with the treachery, and unkingly conduct of the last of the Stuarts.

Under King William the Coldstream Regiment served in the Flanders Campaign. It was Caidz and Vigo, at the beginning of the war of the Spanish Succession. Some companies were among the succour thrown into Gibraltar after its capture by Rooke; and subsequently served in Spain, under Galway and Peterborough, and at the battle of Alamanza. The regiment was not in Marlborough's earlier campaing; but in 1708, four companies (afterwards increased to six) formed in battalion with some companies of the first Guards, were sent to Flanders, and worthily represented the regiment at the great victories of Ocdenarde and Malplaquet, and at many sieges and encounters - including the capture of the Standard of the French Guards at Neer Landendown, to the peace of 1713 when they returned home from Dunkirk. The regiment took part in the Vigo Expadition of 1719.

The 1st Battalion fought at Dettingen and Fontenoy, and was in Scotland during the Rebellion of 1745. The 2nd battalion was at the seige of Bergen-op-zoom two years later, served on the French coast in 1757 and afterwards served in the campaign of 1760 in Germany, under the Marquis of Granby. The regiment contributed its quota to the contingent of Guards which served in America down to the surrender at York Town.

At the outbreak of the French Revolutionary War the 1st Battalion embarked with the brigade of guards under Lake. It fought at St. Amand, near Famers, on the 9th May 1793, one of the first encounters of the enmey , when the brunt fell on the Steramers, who behaved with a spirit nothing could exceed. They fought at Lincelles, and in many other affairs in the subsequent war, and shared in the winter retreat to Breman. The regiment was represented in Ireland, and at Ostend in 1798 and in North Holland in 1799. The 1st Battalion served under Sir J. M. PUlteney, at Ferrol and Vigo, and eventually Sir Ralph Abercromby's forces in Marmorice Bay, and accompanied them to Egypt.

At the landing of the British I Aboukir Bay, the Coldstreams waded ashore in heavy marchin gorder, under a tremendous cannonade, from which they suffered heavily, losing more men than all the rest of the force put together. They participated in the battle of Alexandri a21st March, 1801, where the gallant Abercrombie fell in the moment of victory, and in the subsequent siege of Alexandria they bore a prominent part and after the surrender of the French garrison, forme dpart of the force ordered to occupy the city. The battalion left Egypt immendiately afterwards, and after a delay of three weeks in Malta, returned home. Its services in egypt are symbolized by the "Schinx." with the word "Egypt" on the regimental colours of all three battalions.

The 1st battalion served in the expedition to Hanover in 1805, and at Copehagen in 1807. Its embarked for the TAgus, under command of General Sherbrooks, in January, 1809, and subsequently served at the passage of the

Douro, the capture of Oporto, and the battles of Talavera and Barossa, also in the subsequent campaigns of 1810, including the sieges of Ciudad Rodrigo, Badejos, Burogs, and St. Sebastian the battles of Fuentes d'Onor, Salamances, Vittoria, Pyrenees, bidossoa, Nive, Nivelle, and the investment of Bayonne and up to the walls of Paris.

The flank companies of the 2nd Battalion were in the Walcheren Expedition and some companies of the same Battalion served under Graham at Cadiz, and at the battle of BArossa. These companies aftwards returned home. In 1813, six companies of the 2nd Battalion proceeded to Holland, and took . part I the assult on Bergen-op-Zoom. these companies remained in garrison in Belgium after the peace being quated at Brussels, and then at Ath. On the eascape of Napolen from Elba they were reinforced from home by four more companies of the 1st Battalion, and represented the regiment at the battles of Quatre Bras and Waterloo. The 2nd Battalions of the Coldstreams and 3rd (now Scots) Guards, formed the second Brigade of Guards, commanded by Sir JOhn Byng. On the 18th June, the Second Brigade of Guards was posted on the ridge above Hougoment, on the right side of Maitlan'ds Guards, and to part of the Coldstream battalion tell the honour of defending the Chateu of Hougomount - the key of the british position - throughout that memorable day. The Battalion took part in the occupation of Paris remaining in France until the summer of 1816.

The 1st Battalion was in Portugal in 1897 28, and the 2nd Battalion was in Canada during the disturbances of 1838. It was about this time that King William IV. ordered the regiment to adopt the bearskin, which had only been worn previously by the Grenadier companies.

At the outbreak of the Crimean War, the 1st Battalion embarked for the East with the Duke of Cambridge's division, with which it served in the battles of the Alma, and Inkerman and in the siege of Sebastopol, in all of which it covered itself with glory, particulary in the "Soldiers' Battle" of that memorable 5th Novemeber, 1834.

The Coldstreamers were not called upon to take the field again till the Egyptian War of 1882, when the 1st Battalion went out and fought in various actions, and went over the trenches of Tel el-Kebir. The 2nd Battalion was also engaged in the Suskin Expedition of 1885, and both battalions supplied detachedments to the Canal Corps operating with the columns attempting to bring succour to Gordon in Khartoom.

During the late South Africa War the 1st and 2nd Battalions represented the regiment, and the prowess of the Guards in may a stubborn action is yet too fresh in the public mind to dilate upon here. Suffice it to say that the Coldstreamers of the present day proved that they were worthy successors to the dead and gone heroes whose bones whitened the plains and hills of Europe in the days of Marlborough and Wellington, or lie in the valles before Skastopol. As already announced in these notes, the 3rd Coldstreamers are earmarked for reduction under Mr. Halden's scheme, but something occuring in the political world may save it. It is to be hoped so in the interests of the army.

div.head: RETURN OF THE VENUS.
div.p: H.M.S. Venus arrived at Alexandria at five o'clock yesterday evening from Port Said. The length of stay of H.M.S. Venus in the port of Alexandria is uncertain at present, but she will probably stay there until the return of Lord Cromer from home. We regret to learn that Captain Eyre of the Venus is laid up at Port Said hospital suffereing from typoid fever. He is progressing very favourably.

div.head: LANCASHIRE COTTON SPINNERS.
div.p: Lancashire cotton psinners have given other instance of their enterprise. It is reported that syndicate has bought a tract of land in Brownwill, Texas, to the extent of 4,000 acres, in order to cultivate the growth of cotton. For a number of years English spinners have been looking about for a suitable place to grow raw material believing that the cost would be thereby reduced. A few months ago several Manchester employers visited the cotton belt and mada careful inquiry into the culture of cotton. More land is inteded to be bought if the present experiment succeeds.
The Commission appointed by the Lancashire Cotton Spinners has reported in favour of the spinners sequiring land for growing cotton in the American Belt. (Reuter)

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON.
div.p: The following New York calbe has been received from Messrs. Collinge Bros.:
Killing frost in some sections, Oklahoma Arkanasa, Mississipi, Tennessee with more frost threatened in the Altantics tonight. Spinners nervous, Crop estimates are being reduced.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Mr. Machell, Adviser of the Minsitry of the Interior, arrived at Port Said yesterday by the P and O Osiris. He was met by Khali Bey Rias, deputy governor of the Canal, Miralai Thomas Shaloh Bey, commanding the Canal police. Bimbashi F. Bonelli, Inspector of the Police, and Mr. John Tarrell, Director of Customer, Mr. Machell lefy by the neon train for Cairo.
Masloum Pasha, Minister of Finance, return from Europe on the 20th inst.

M. Maskens, Belgian Agent at Cairo, is mentioned for appointment to the Legratio at the Quirinal. His sucessor will be M. Sainetelette, Consul Genral at Brazil. It is also stated that M. Rooman Erthuer, first secretary, has been promoted elsewhere, and will be succeeded by M. de Lichtervalds.
Its is rumoured that the marquis Pallavicisi, Austrian Minsiter at Bucharest, who has been transferred to Constantionolpe will be asucceeded by Count Bolesta Kodisbrdski, Diplamtic Agent at Cairo.
Mr. Nams, manager of the Sucreries Co, has arrived from Europe.
Ahmed Bey Haled, Judge of the Native Court of Alexandria, and Mestapha Bey Wassif, Judge of the Tribunal of Keneh, have applied for their pensions.
Vice Admiral A.C. Clarks and Major Des Voeux have arrived at Port Said by the Bibbd S.S. Hersfordshire from Marseilles.
Mr. and Mrs. E.C. Hogg will arrive at Alexandria on the 21st inst. by the S.S. Grosser Kur'urst and will proceed direct to their villa at Ghesireh.
Mr. H. B. Greville has returned to CAiro from Europe today.

Major General J.P. Story, lately in command of the Philippine Army passed through the Canal yesterday on board the U.S. transport Meads, en route for New York. Major General Story is said to have been summoned to command the American troops in Cuba.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsbiel for the opinions expressed by our coresspondents in a spirit of fair play to all to permit - within certain necessary limits free discussion.

div.head: SENSATIONAL NEWS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, - Will you allow me in your valuable columns to draw the attention of these responsible, and irresponsible, to the harm that is done to Egypt by the publisation senational news as cultivated by the present day correspondent. Upon one or two facts of slight importance, are built the most monstrous fabrications. They are easily wrecked by the first puff of truth, but unhappliy the public aborad may only read the first sotry, and miss the categorial denial. The result is that people of nervous temperament are actually frightened away. Why only the other day an oldy lady wrote to me, anxiously enquiring whether there was any "Unrest in Egypt" before she would start for Assouan. Surely some measure ought to be adopted for occasionally muzzling news mongers of these higly flavoroued wares, if only for the sake of these whose livelihood depoends on the tourist. - Yours, etc.
Resident.

div.head: STREETS OF CAIRO.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, - There is hardly a corner of the busiest thoroughfares in Ciaro where is not to be found a cafe with seats and tables in front, which not alone fill up the footway but in some instances extend partly across the road. This greatly adds to the dangers of pedstrians, as likewise the sticky state of the freshly watered roads, which are brushed but never scraped, as they ought to be. The flith consequently gets chavned up by the traffic, and crossing the road without stumbling is a matter of great difficulty. The roads, too, ought to be watered with a mixture of Jaye's Fluid. the odour from the moist filth is most offensive and harmful to health and comfor. - Yours truly,
Objector.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd hiu a midi et demie.)

Eu depit de la hausse du taux d'escompte a Londres et a Berlin et de la tenue reservee des valeurs sur les marches europeus, ici nous avons eu une reporse generale plus ou moimarques. L'activite se limite pourtant a la Cassa di Sconto, aux Nungovich Hotels, Delta Land, Estates, Comptoir et Hooker. Ajoutons que les banques en general et particulierement l'Agricole et la National Bank sont provisoire ment delaissees.
La Cassa di Sconto s'avance de 228 a 229 ¼ l'ancienne et la nouvelle de 222 ½ a 224 ¼.
En gain de ¼ les Nungovich Hotels atteingnent le prix de 17 15/16.
Les Delta Land Gagnet encore 1/16 a 3 19/32.
De 1 29/32 l'action Estates passe a 1 15/16 On achete la part de foundateur a 13 livres.
Les Hooker continuent a etre traies a 1 3/32
Quant au Comptoire, l'ancienne emission gage 1/8 a 7 1/32, la nouvelle 3/32 a 6 ¾ et la part de foundatuer 1 livre a 45.
Mais la ne s'arrete pas la hausse de nos titres.

La Behera gane 1/8 a 36 ¾ les Egyptian Markets 9 pence a 27/3, la Salt and soda 7 pence ½ a 22, l'Obligation Credit Foncier Egyptien 75 centimes 1 338, la Banque d'Athenes 7 francs a 144 ½ l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail 6 pence a 35/6, les Building Lansd 1/16 a 5, l'Union Fonciere 1/16 a 6 et la Banque d'Orient 75 centimes a 131 ¾.
Les seules exceptions a cette hausse generale sont l'Agricole qui perd un 1/32 a 9 21/32, et la Deferred Delta ¼ de livre a 12 ¼.
Tout le reste de la cote demeure sans change ment.

Cette accentuation de la reprise, en coincidence avec les manvauses nouvelles vennes d'Europe, ne peut guere s'expliquer que par l'ouverture annulle de la perodc de hausse. Dans le cas contraire elle eat un signe de fermete exceptionnelle de notre marche.

Le 3 courant le Banco di Roma a inaugre une succurale a Malte. MM. le chev. Cantoni et Bornaccini en ont ete nommes les directeurs. La presse de l'ile et la colonie italienne ont accueilli avec enthousiasme l'ouverture de ce nouveau siege et tout donne a penser qu'il prosperera.
Depuis mardi la corbeille des valeurs au Caire reste ouverts jsqu'a midi et demie. Quant a la séance du samedi, elle y sera raprise a partir d'apres demain, 13 courant.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

A Loudres, le consolide angalis a gagre hier 1/8 a 86 5/8. L'Unifiee est restee invaree a 104 ½, de meme que la National Bank a 26 7/8. l'Agricole a 9 ¾ e t la Delta Light a 11 5/8. La Diara a avance de 1/8 a 16 7/8.
A Paris, l'action Credit Froncier Egyptian a retrograde de 1 franc a 778. La Banque d'Athenes est demeuree inchanges a 144. L'emprunt russe 1906 a reactionne de 83.50 a 83.20.

Ici, la tendance genearle se maintient ferme. Le compartiment des tires dirigeants a ete, il est vrasi, calme, aveo des transcations tres clairsemees; mais, en revanche, les affaires praquess ont ete nombreuses dans les autres groupes, notamment dans celui des petites valeurs.
Dans l'ensemble , l'orientation semble etre toujours a la hausse, retenue en grande partis par la penurie d'or dont la fin ne saurait se produire avant les premirs jours la semaine prochaine.
La National Bank a ete traitee a 26 ¾-13/6. L'Agricole est restee a 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a molli a 227-228. La Bauque d'Orient a progresse a 132 et le Comptoir Fnancier a 6 7/8.
L'action Credit Foncier s'est maintenne a 776; la part de fondatue a nouvean gagne 20 franc a 980; l'obligation a lots ancienne a reactionne a 337-338.
La Behera a encore avance de 1/8 a 36 3/1. L'action Enterprise and Development a ete mienx tenue a 12 7/8 et la part de fondateur a 22-22 1/8. Les Improvements sont revenus a 5 5/8-11/16.
L'action Entreprises Immobilieres et Tranvauz a gane 1/16 a 4 3/8-7/16; tonjours en bonne demande, la part de fondateur a cloture a 85.

Assez mouvementee, la Delta Light a passe de 11 ¾ a 11 7/8. Les Jouissances Eaux de Caire se sout alourdies a 265 et la Frigori fique a 4 7/8. Les Automoblies du Caire ont beneficie de plus de ¼ a 6 3/8 7/16; la part de fondateur a hausse de 3/8 a 11 ¼.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hotelieres, le Nungovich ont ete pousses a 17 13/16 pour cloturer a 17 1/16 3/1. Les Egyptian ont avance a 6 7/16 1.2. Les Upper Egypt ont cloture a leur prix d'hier, soit 5 1/16 1/8.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont gagne 1/16 a 3 ½. Les Estates ont ete large ment enchanges entre 1 29/32 et 1 13/16 pour finir a ce dernier prix; la part de fondateur a debute a 12 3/16 pour atteindre les abords de 13 et terminer a 12 ¾ 1/16. Les Markets se sont raffermia 25 ah. 6, les Abdy a 1 3/16 ¼ la Khedivial Mail a 35 sh. 3.
Nous detachons d'une lettre de Paris, en date du 3 Octobre, le passage suivant:

"La vive repirse des fonds russes rejette ici au second plan toutes les pre occupations de la speculation, en ce quie concerne notamment le rencherissement du taux de l'argent et de la discussion de nouvelles mesures discales a la retree des Chambres. Les nouvelles de Russie representatn, en effect, que l'ordre se retablit u a peu et que le reprise du travail s'accentu.

"Plus encourageante encore est la confiance renaissante de la speculation; elle est l'indice d'un heureuz revirement de son etat d'esprit. Comme la depression des fond russes etait jusqu'ici le principal obstacle a la continuation de la hausse generale, leur relvement constite un symptome des plus caracteristiques et des plus rassurants."
La sonscription publique a 20,00 actions de la Societe Ottamane des Tramways et de Electricite de Beyrouth a ete ouverte la semaine derniere a Bruzelles, a L ege et a Constantinople.
Cette Societe a ete consituee a Constantinople le 4 Juin 1906, au capital de 3,600,000 de francs. Il a ete cree, en outre, 3,800 parts de fondateur. La duree de la concession est de 99 ans.
Les 20,00 actions precitees out ete offertes en souscription au prix de Frs. 117,50 payables 37,50 a la soucription, 40 a la repartition et 40 le 15 Novembre prochain.

Le premier conseil d'adminsitration est compose de MM. Nedjid pacha Melhame. Victor Limague, Selim Raad, Adolphe Latouz, Philippe Melhame, Charles Thonet, Etouard Denis, Habib Melhame et Issac Fernandez.

div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that those shareholders in the above Company who have not yet paid all their calls on shares held by them myst pay same on or before the 30th October 1906 to the Company's Baukers, the Anglo-Egyptian Bank Limited, Alexandria.

Having regard to the amalagamariem of the Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. with the Building Lands of Egypt its is necessary that all calls should be paid by the date above indicated, and further, shareholders owing calls will be unable to obtain their new shares in exchange for their present ones until they have paid their shares up in full. div.head:
PRINCE HOHENLOHE'S DIARY.
THE KAISER DISSAPROVES.

div.p: Great general interst has been excited by the publication of the diary of the former Chancello, Prince Hohenlohe, comprising the narration of the Emperor William's own description to the Prince of the three deplorable weeks preceeding Prince Bismarck's downfall. He mentions various heated discussion on labour questions which took place between the Emperor and the Prince. The final separation was largely due to the Emperor's refusal to countenance Prince Bismarck's policy of favouring Russia to the detriment of Germany's Austrian ally. The Emperor told Prince Hohenlohe that is the final itnerview Dismarck enarly threw the ink-pot at him. It was generally concluded that the publication of the diary at the present moment was due tot he Emperor's desire to propitiate Austria by testifying to his old loyalty to the alliance, but His Majesty yesterday telegraphed to the head of the House of Hohenlohe condemning to the publication as arrant and tactless. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE RUSSIAN TERRORISTS.
21 SHOT IN POLAND.

div.p: Twenty-one terrorits were tried by drumhead court martial in Poland, and shot, within the last two days. (Reuter)
The police have arrested in the workmen's quarter a number of people who were preparing bombs and munitions. (Havas)
Onlawry continues, despire its repression. A general strike and emonstration took place at Lodz Zgiez and Pabjanice. (Havas)

div.head:
BRITISH DEPUTATION TO DUMA.
PUBLIC RECEPTION PROHIBITED.

div.p: The Perfect has intimated that he cannot permit a public reception of the British deputation, which purposes to honour the ex Dumatits who are accused to crimes against the State. (Reuter)

It is understood that certain pressue is being exercised from high quarters for the purpose of inducing the deputation to Russia to abandon its visit to that country for feat of creating indcidents calculated to disturb the progress which has unquestionablky been made latterly towards a definite Anglo-Russian entente. (Reuter)
Mr. Taft has granted amnesties for all crimes in connection with the revolution. This is expected to facilitaet Mr. Magoon's work. (Reuter)

div.head:
WIRELESS TELEGRAPHY CONFERENCE.
ENGLAND'S PROPOSALS UNSUPPORTED.

div.p: The "Daily Mail" learns from Berlin that England has been pratically isolated in the International Wireless Telgraphy /conference. Italy is the only Power supporting BRitish opposition to Germany's proposal that the interchange of communication at sea should be regarless of a particular system. The British postal delegates were willing to waive the opposition, but the Admiralty feel bound by the Marconi contract. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE PANAL CANAL.
INVITATIONS FOR TENDERS.

div.p: Invitations for tenders to complete the Panama Canal have been issued. The bidders are not limited to Americans, but must have a capital of 5,000,000 dollars. (Reuter)
The cure for sleeping sickness at Leopoldville is quinine and atonyl combined with warm and cold showe baths. (Reuter)
The eight-hour full speed trials of the Dreadrought were most satisfactory. The vessel developed a speed of 22 ½ knots an hours. No vibration was felt. (Reuter)

div.dateline: Cessrewitch Stakes. 1. Mintagon; 2. Bibiani; 3. Royal Dream.
div.p: 24 ran. Won by 6 lengths, a length and a half dividing second and thrid. Betting 6 to 1 against Mintagon, 100 to 15 against Bibiani, and 100 to 6 against Royal Dream. (Reuter)

div.head: EGYPT'S FUTURE.
"QUITE INNOCUOUS."
div.p: Mr. Robert William, F.R.I.B.A, a well known Lodon architect, has for some time been in the habit of spending a considrable part of every year in Egypt, where he has extensive professional interests. He is keenly interested in Egypt and the Egyptians and is much impressed by the industrial and commerical potentialities of the ancient land, which owes its marvellous regeneration in these latter days to the guiding hand and protecting arm of England.

"I am not a all perturbed," said Mr. Williams to a "Daily Chronicle" representative, by the talk of a vast Pan-Islamic agitation. Pan-Islamism is an innocuous as Pan-Celticism. The idea that Moslem is a fantic is fallacious. I have mized with all classes of the Egyptians; have travelled alone for hundreds of miles through the country, and have never been subjected to the slightest annoyance.

"You ask me if the people are grateful for the blessings of justic, orderly government, and prosperity which have followed in the wake of the British occupation. Yes; I think they are. But just now there is a very bitter feeling of resentment against the British for the haste and the severity of the punishments in the DEnishwai affairs. That has left burning mermories. Nobody can deny that the British have helped the Egyptians and have done marvellous things in the apst twenty four years in the interest of Egypt. The country enhoys considerable prosperity, although there is a great deal yet to be done to develop its industrial potentialities. As an instance of the prosperity of Egypt I may tell you from personal knowledge that at the present timeland in Alexandria fetches from £50,000 to £60,000 an acre. Land values, urban and rural, have greatly appreciated in recent years. It is unfortunate that this rapid development attracts the gambler and dubious company promoter. As the Egyptian himself is a born gambler, these parasites of commerce find in Egypt a congenial field.
The Nationalist Movement.

"As to the Nationalist novement. I do not thnk it has, as yet, taken definite form. The better educated people undoubtedly demand a voice in the government of the country. Their favourite is, 'Give us a Parliament like the British House of Common.' Yet they have crude ideas of Parliamentary instituations. Not long ago I had a talk with a typical Egyptian of the educated class."
"We want a Parliament of our own," he told me, "modelled on your."
"Do you want a House of Lords" I asked.
"No, no," was the reply.
"Do you want manhood suffrage"
"Certanily not. We would confine the vote to landowners, master craftsmen, shopkeepers, and resident Europeans."
"What about the workers. Would you not give them the vote"
"No; they are too ignorant."
"Would you give the vote to women"
"indeed, no; the woman's place is the house, to mind the children and bake the bread."
Moslem Fanaticism.
"You will see from this fragment of conversation that the educated Egyptian has crude ideas of democracy."

"Egypt has many acute social problems confronting her at the present time. In the towns there is a housing problem, and there are other gross social evils. The difficulty of dealing with these is aggravated by the indifference and the fatalism of the Oriental. There is no sustained or widely-diffused interest in politics.

The fame of the wealth of Lower Egypt having penetrated into Upper Egypt and the Sudan, an influx of Berberin and Sudansese has been the natural consequence. Many of these are lump hobbledehoys, who manage to live on the barest fare, lodging in any odd corners. They are hardy sons of the soil, and need neither bed nor covering. To them and their like (for the want of something better on which to expand their strength) together with the Alexandrian shoeblack, was due the riot of last Christmas, but which was intially provoke dby two gambling Greeks and their evolvers.

The municipality of Alexandria are now endeavouring to induce the surplus Berberin, etc., to return to their own country, on the upper reaches of the Nile where they can always find cultivating work to do, often on their own bit of land.

Don't believe in all this talk of Moslem fanaticism. It's a mere scare. The religion of Islam is perhaps the most democratic in the world, and in time it may develop in those who profess it the idea of the brotherhood of man, which underlies it, alon ght lines of Socialism.

To help the Arabs we can do much if each one of us were to remember that the Egyptian judges of our country and intentions by what he sees in us individually. As our actions are noble or ignoble so will be judge of the nation to which it is our privilege to belong. At one time the Arbas used to say that a thing was as true "as the word of an Englishman." It behoves us to live up to this noble tradition.

"Let England help the Egyptians to develop the great underdeveloped resources of the country; let her help to check the ravages of the money-lender and exploiter; let her help the Egyptian to a complete system of elementary, technical, and higher education; let her help gradually, but surely, to pave the way to self-government. Then we shall crown the beneficent work we have done in Egypt."

Mr. Williams had much to say on the architecture of Egypt past and present. The Egyptians have deteriorated in this great art of which hygone centuries they were the leaders of the world. "I am doing what I can," he said, in my own sphere to induce the egyptian builders to use those splendid materials which the ancient Egyptians employed with such marvellous results in their temples and pyramids. These materials still abound in the country. At Assouan there is an unlimited supply of beautiful granite, both red and grey, as well as diorite. Then at Silsillah ther are vast sandstone quarries, and at Bassatin there is some excellent limestone. All this fine material is left unused, and in its place the builders of today use much inferior stone and brick without anything like its beauty or its lasting power."

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

There is a general feeling that great credit is due to the Directors of the Bank of England in declining to be anxious in face of the further heavey withdrawls of gold that have taken place during the week. It would be a good thing if the financial community generally took a lesson from their hard-headed common-sense, for, reviewing the situation ina dispaasionate manner, there is no reason for any anxiety as regards the money market at present, nor is there likely to be so far as common sense can reason it out. The American demand has come and gone, and not withstanding this being a heavy drain the proportion of reserve is ony 1.8 below that of last year. At the same time the accumulations in the Treasury at New York, and the untouched positions of the reserves in France, are an usually strong piont. that these should be kept to a certain extent in reserve, after all, makes for steadiness, and the drop in the price of gold is an unmistakable sign that the supply is overtaking the demand. The unknown factor for the moment in Egypt, and it is not supposed that the crop there can be moved without several millions being withdrawn. These withdrawls, however, are likely to be counter-balanced by supplies from the mines, whjich will be redirected to this country now that the demand from America has eased off. It is not possible to foretell with any certainty, but the general feeling here is that the corner has been turned, and that the crisis, if such it can be called, is passed.

It is very encouraging to see in a report made by the Committee of Investigation in the United States on the currency question a very sensible suggestion for the establishment of an Issue Bank under control not connected with the Government and mainly a bankers' bank. This departue is as nearly as possible a copy of our own excellent system, excepting that the Bank of Issue, as we understand it, will not take ordinary business to compete with the other banks and will be more under Government control. That some means was necessary to put the note issue in America on a more elastic basis is admitted by all. A state bank would appear to be not only good and practicable, but on the lines of the least resistance.

The Bank return this week shows a reduction of reserve amounting to £2,979,000, and the decline in the ratio of the reserve to liabilities is 4 3/8 percent., which, however, is only 1/8 percent less than at this time last year.
The Stock Markets.

Although there has again been a certain amount of nervousness - uncessary nervousness, we think - regardin the money position, the undertone has been decidely good since our last, and we are informed by the most prominent brokers on the Stock Exchange that there was more steady buying this week than for months past, more for investment than speculation. Should the money market show increased ease, as we have a right to expect, it is higly probable that the activity in stocks will be largely enhanced. In some quarters ther was an inclinatino to criticise the Bank Directors, but the general feeling now ist hat they are best able to gauge the future of money, to 5 per cent was a wise one. Certainlu as regard the stock markets this decision has had a good effect, espcially on first-class stocks, and there is no reason to doubt that in the rear future, with a normal money position, we shall see a really substantial revivial of acitivy. This is a desideratum that has long been looked ofr, and dealers have almost grown weary of waiting for it, but this week they have received some encouragement, which is accepted as omen of better things to come.
Consols.
The Consol settlement has been effected this week, and the carry over price showed a loss of a full point on the account, the compartive quotations being 87 3/8 last time, and 86 3/8 on Wednesday.

Business in the gilt edged market has again been influenced by the heavy go with drawals from Threadneedle Stree, and anticipation of a further increase in the Bank rate. on the announcement of no change yesterday the prce of Consols improved to 86 ¾, but fell back to 86 5/8, and closed unchanged on the day.They leave off tonight at 86 ½.
Foreign Bonds.

After the slight relapse Russian bonds had a sharp recovery, and the script of the new Fives have been as goos as 8 1/8 discount. The reports which appear in this mornings newspapers regarding the very grave condition of Russian finances, and the absolute necessity for another loan being floated to meet the heavy deficit on the year's working have, however, caused a set back, and the bonds close weak, the Four at 72 ¼ and the new loan at 10 ¼ discount. Japanese Four and a Half per cents were in active demand yesterday, the price gaining 1/8 at 95 ½, at which they close tonight. The weakness of Turks is a prominent feature of the market, the Unified yesterday losing 3/6 at 93 ½ Ottoman Banks also dropped to ¼ to 16 3/8.
Home Ralls.
The capture by the Socialists of the Railway men's Union, added to the already existing

fears of labour troubles, mentioned in our report last week, dearer money, and relisations by stale bulls reduced this market to a helpless condition. The low prices touched, however, brought in some buying orders and this gave an improved appearnce, which was enhanced by the retention of the Bank rate 4 1/2%. Great Northern Deferred were very depressed at one time, the price being forced down to 40 1/8, the lowest point touched during the year, and this in spite of a traffic increases of over £6,000 The shares have since received some support, and close better at 41 ¾. The market generally has an improved tone today.
Americans.

American railway shares maintained a firm tone for the two or three days this week, but the disppointment felt at the Aitchison dividend at the rate of 5 per cent., which is 1 per cent less than had been anticipated, cast a gloom over the market yesterday.

Aitchison shares were put down 4 ¼ points to 107 ¼, Chicago-milwaukee lost 1, while in the most of the other cases there were losses from ¼ to 7/8. Southern Pacifics were the only firm section, these gaining 1. The market has been quiet today, and the changes are few and insignifant. Aitchison have recovered 1/8, and Steels ¼, but Unions have lost 5/8, and Milwaunkee ½ Canadian Pacifics are 1 ¼ lower.
Egyptians.

Firmness has characetised the Egyptian market, and although there has been litt of interest passing,prices generally show a deciding improvement. During the early part of the week National Banks were dealt in to a considerable extent, and at one time wer 27 buyers, but have since dropped back to 26 ¾, at which price they leave off tonight. The new Land Bank issue which is being offered to the public is not looked upon very favourably. Before providing this corporation with a further sume of £1,800,00 it seems desirable to enquire whether the security is ample, and whether it bears a satisfactory relation to the moneys subscribed by the British public. Lands Banks clsoe tonight at 9 which is the same as last Friday. New Egyptians have again revived, quite a large number of the shares having changed hands. They leave off 1 ½ Egyptian Estates are form at 1 7/8 and Corportaion of Western Egypt at 3/8 premium.
Mining.

The South African market has been almost devoid of interest , and for the greater part of the week there has been pratically nothing doing. In the absence of support, shares dropped considerably, but yesterday towards the close there was a little professional dealing in some of the shares. As a result of this, Rand Mines, after being offered at 5 18/19, picked up to buyers at 6, why Goldields recovered from sellers to buyers at 4 1/16 after being sellers under the figure. In the Rhodesian section Tanagyikes hardened to 6 ½ and Bankets to 2 1/8 Rand Mines leave off tonight at 6 and Tangayikes at 6 9/16.

Egyptian minig shares continue quiet but firm United Africans, which spurted to 1,19.32 last Friday, leave off tonight at 1,17/32. Nile Valleys after being irregular show little change on the week at 6 3d.
The Um Rus meeting passed off satisfactorily yesterday, the shareholders appearing to be satisfied with the policy of the directors. The shares close unchanged.

div.head: Commerical and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commerical and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturdat in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stoc and share markets, with all the lastest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cooton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT

Egyptian on the spot continues neglected, and prices generally are easier. Fir Brown and all Uppes are unchanged, but Good Fair Brown is reduced ¼ d per lb. lower. In Futures a fairly good businees has been done, and the latest values are: -

American Futures.- The market this week has experienced an enormous business, and a complete change of front. The "Bears," alarmed by a devastating hurricane in the Southern States, the extent of damage resultinf from which is still uncertain, although undoubtedly serious, rushed in to buy, and prices rose over 50 points in 3 days; there has subsequently been a sharp reaction of 20 points from the extreme rates touched yesterday afternoon Closing valyes are, however, from the injury by storm the weather reports generally are not considerable favourable, rains continue in most districts, and ther is a decided tendency to more conseravative estimates of the yield. We tink that great nervousness and constant flucutations, probably shapr ones, will mark the immediate future, especially during the next 2 or 3 weeks, on account of the liabilit to frost scares, which would be paraticularly disastrous this season, the plant being in a wet condition. The market will require careful watching.We think that purchases mad ein drpressed moments will be profitable, for we believe that all ideas of a bumper yield, so confidently, and that the large requirements of consumers will eventually bring about a higher level of prices.

div.head: Supplement Commerical et Financier de "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Le Supplement Commerical et Financier de "l'Egyptian Gazette" parait caque Samedi a midi, de facon a pouvoir etre expedie par le paquebot autrichien. Il contieut des revues completes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marche des valeurs; les denieres statistiques jusqu'a la veilre de sa publication: de tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des depches officielles envoyees a la Liverpool Cotton Association, ete. etc.
L'abonnement pour une anne en Egypte clotue L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'estranger 10 P.T. de port en aus.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS.
div.p: NOTICE.

The Egyptian State Railways have the honour to inform the Public that commencing from Thursday, 11h October, a new station called Masalla siturated at Kilox.706750 between Shagab and Matana will be opened for booking passengeres and grand vitesse goods only, and the following traius will stop there to pick up and set down passengers: -
Cairo, 1st October, 1906
GENERAL MANAGER.
